content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State child support enforcement agencies can only disclose obtained financial records for the purpose of establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. The Child Support Enforcement Agency can only disclose financial records obtained from a financial institution for the purpose of establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Civil damages can be sought for unauthorized disclosure by a state officer or employee. If a state officer or employee discloses a financial record of an individual in violation of the law, the individual can sue the state for damages in federal court. There is no liability if the disclosure was made in good faith but based on an erroneous interpretation of the law. Damages can be sought in such cases. In cases of unauthorized disclosure of financial records, liability may not apply if the disclosure was made in good faith but based on an erroneous interpretation of the law. Damages can be sought in such instances, with specific amounts outlined for each act of unauthorized disclosure. The liability for unauthorized disclosure of financial records can result in a minimum of $1,000 per act or the sum of actual damages plus punitive damages for willful or grossly negligent disclosures. Unauthorized disclosure of financial records can result in punitive damages for willful or grossly negligent disclosures, in addition to actual damages and the costs of the action. Definitions for "depository institution" are provided in this section. The term "financial record" is defined in the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978. It includes depository institutions, institution-affiliated parties, Federal and State credit unions, and their affiliated parties. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a State agency that manages a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies can access and use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity has been established or acknowledged by the consumer. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity has been established or acknowledged by the consumer, in accordance with State laws. The agency must provide written notice to the consumer before obtaining the consumer report and certify to the consumer reporting agency that the requirements have been met. The State agency must certify to the consumer reporting agency that the requirements for obtaining a consumer report have been fulfilled. The term 'State child support enforcement agency' is defined as a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. In Child Support Orders, Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for any child support order issued or modified by a court or administrative agency of the State. Procedures for child support orders issued or modified by a court or administrative agency of the State must include coverage of the child's health care costs according to state guidelines and expedited handling of noncompliance allegations. The State must establish guidelines for the coverage of children's health care costs under child support orders as a condition for plan approval. Each State must establish guidelines for covering children's health care costs under child support orders to have its State plan approved, meeting minimum standards set by the Secretary in regulations. The Secretary will establish regulations with minimum standards for guidelines on covering children's health care costs under child support orders, including the contents of the order, responsibility distribution, and provisions for health insurance coverage and claims payment. The regulations will cover guidelines for children's health care costs under child support orders, including responsibility distribution, health insurance provisions, denial of coverage circumstances, penalties for non-compliance by insurance providers. The regulations will cover guidelines for children's health care costs under child support orders, including responsibility distribution, health insurance provisions, denial of coverage circumstances, penalties for non-compliance by insurance providers, and considerations for changes in parents' circumstances. The Secretary shall ensure that the State prioritizes the best interests of the child when establishing guidelines. The Secretary shall ensure that State guidelines for children's health care costs under child support orders consider the best interests of the child, parents' financial circumstances, and cost-effectiveness. Regulations must be proposed within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must issue proposed regulations within 9 months and final regulations within 14 months to implement the amendments made by this subsection. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to issue final regulations within 14 months to implement the amendments made by this subsection regarding the inclusion of dependent health insurance in the Incentive Payments Program. The Social Security Act is amended to consider successful enforcement of a support order for health insurance as support collection from the absent parent. The Social Security Act is amended to include support collected from enforcing health insurance provisions for children as part of the absent parent's support payments. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services within six months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe regulations within six months to implement the amendment regarding support payments for children's health insurance. Additionally, a study will be conducted to determine incentives for states to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for health and dental expenses. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide incentives to states to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses, including obtaining medical insurance coverage. A report on the results will be submitted to the relevant committees within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit the results of a study to the relevant committees within 12 months of the Act's enactment. Section 452(a)(10) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new requirement for annual reports on state compliance with child support assistance time limits. Compliance with established standards must be reported by each state. Employers must withhold wages to pay child support obligations and remit the payments to the state within 10 days. A penalty is imposed on employers for late payments. Employers must remit child support payments to the state within 10 days of withholding wages. A $1,000 penalty is imposed on employers who fail to make timely payments. Employers who fail to remit child support payments within 10 days will incur a $1,000 penalty. The State must use all collected penalties for the operation of the State plan approved under section 454. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to wages paid on or after that date. The amendments made by subsection (a) of this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to wages paid on or after such date and payments under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters beginning on or after such date. Delay permitted if state legislation required for State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act. The amendments made by subsection (a) of this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to wages paid on or after such date and payments under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters beginning on or after such date. In the case of a State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act, the State plan shall not be regarded as failing to comply with the requirements solely on the basis of not meeting additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter beginning after the close of the 1st regular. The State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act shall not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing states to locate absent parents owing child support or involved in visitation enforcement by accessing records from other state agencies. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing states to access records from other state agencies and federal sources to locate absent parents owing child support or involved in visitation enforcement. States can also access files from other states to identify additional child support orders involving the same absent parent. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing states to access records from other state agencies and federal sources to locate absent parents owing child support or involved in visitation enforcement. States can access files from other states to identify additional child support orders involving the same absent parent. The system allows for online and batch processing of locate requests, with online access restricted to cases needing immediate information and batch processing used for periodic updates. Requests are directed to individual states. The Parent Locator Service expands into a national network, allowing states to access records from other state agencies and federal sources to locate absent parents owing child support or involved in visitation enforcement. The system allows for online and batch processing of locate requests, with a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for information to be broadcast and returned to a requesting State. The national network of the Parent Locator Service allows states to access records from other state agencies and federal sources to locate absent parents owing child support or involved in visitation enforcement.
